title: Stakeholder Adoption of Requirements
statement: These requirements have since been used by a variety of stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and several country governments, including that of Bangladesh.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence of use or adoption by OpenHIE is documented.
Evidence of use or adoption by openIMIS is documented.
Evidence of use or adoption by the government of Bangladesh is documented.

metadata.raw_input: These requirements have since been used by a variety of stakeholders, including the Open Health Information Exchange (OpenHIE), the open source Health Insurance Management Information System (openIMIS), and several country governments, including that of Bangladesh.

title: Update to National Health Insurance Information Systems Guide
statement: The information system must be updated to align with the content and requirements specified in the new 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems', which supersedes the 2012 version.
regulation: National Health Insurance Information Systems Guide (Updated)
acceptance_criteria: A gap analysis is performed comparing the current system against the new guide.
All system functionalities, policies, and procedures are reviewed and updated to meet the requirements of the new guide.
A compliance audit successfully validates that the system adheres to all applicable requirements from the updated guide.
Documentation is updated to reflect compliance with the new guide.

metadata.raw_input: A Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems This document, , is the result of that Determining workshop and the next step toward updating the content of the 2012 document.

title: Update National Health Insurance System Requirements Guide
statement: A Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems This document, , is the result of that Determining workshop and the next step toward updating the content of the 2012 document.
acceptance_criteria: The content of the 2012 guide document is reviewed against the findings from the 'Determining workshop'.
A new, updated version of the 'Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems' is drafted and approved.
The final, approved guide is published and distributed to relevant teams.

metadata.raw_input: A Guide to Common Requirements for National Health Insurance Information Systems This document, , is the result of that Determining workshop and the next step toward updating the content of the 2012 document.

title: Living Document Contribution Process
statement: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource.
acceptance_criteria: A formal process for submitting proposed updates is defined and documented.
A mechanism (e.g., web portal, version control repository) is established for the community to submit contributions.
The process for reviewing, approving, and integrating contributions is established and communicated.
The 'living resource' is updated at least once based on a community contribution.

metadata.raw_input: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource.

title: National Health Insurance Systems Introduction
statement: National health insurance systems are becoming more common as countries move to operationalize health financing transactions of paying for and delivering health services as part of their progress toward Universal Health Coverage for their citizens.
acceptance_criteria: This is an introductory, non-functional statement providing context for subsequent requirements. It has no measurable acceptance criteria.

metadata.raw_input: A guide to common requirements for nAtionAl heAlth insurAnce informAtion systems PAge 5 Introduction National health insurance systems are becoming more common as countries move to operationalize health financing transactions of paying for and delivering health services as part of their progress toward Universal Health Coverage for their citizens.

title: Process for Ongoing Requirement Updates
statement: A process shall be established for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure the requirements document remains a valuable and living resource.
acceptance_criteria: A documented process for submitting, reviewing, and incorporating updates from the community is established and accessible.
A designated platform or channel for community contributions is implemented and operational.
The requirements document includes a version history that reflects periodic updates and contributions.

metadata.raw_input: In addition, this document suggests a way forward for the insurance technology community to contribute to ongoing updates to ensure these requirements continue to have value as a living resource. A guide to common requirements for nAtionAl heAlth insurAnce informAtion systems PAge 5 Introduction National health insurance systems are becoming more common as countries move to operationalize health financing transactions of paying for and delivering health services as part of their progress toward Universal Health Coverage for their citizens.

title: National Scale System Importance
statement: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale.
acceptance_criteria: The system architecture must be designed and verified to support a nationwide user base and data volume.
The system must demonstrate compliance with all relevant national-level health data regulations.
System capabilities must be mapped and validated against the functional requirements of the specified national health schemes.

metadata.raw_input: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale.

title: Insurance Information System Effectiveness and Integrity
statement: The health insurance information system must be designed to ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.
regulation: HIPAA Security Rule (45 CFR § 164.308 - Administrative Safeguards)
HIPAA Privacy Rule (45 CFR Part 160 and Subparts A and E of Part 164)
acceptance_criteria: Reimbursement processing time from claim submission to payment must be within the contractually defined Service Level Agreement (SLA), e.g., 30 days.
The system must provide analytics to track and report on transaction costs, demonstrating a measurable decrease over a 6-month baseline.
The system must include a fraud detection module that automatically flags suspicious claims based on predefined rules and machine learning models with a minimum 95% accuracy on test data.
All coverage and treatment decisions made or assisted by the system must be fully auditable to demonstrate non-discriminatory and equitable application of benefits.
The system must generate reports identifying operational inefficiencies, such as common reasons for claim denials or processing bottlenecks.

metadata.raw_input: Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.

title: Health Insurance Information System Core Capabilities
statement: The health insurance information system must be designed to support national-scale schemes by enabling timely reimbursements, decreasing transaction costs, identifying system efficiencies, preventing fraud, and ensuring equitable coverage and treatment.
acceptance_criteria: The system must process and issue decisions on 95% of standard electronic claims within 15 business days.
The system must provide analytics tools to identify and report on transaction cost metrics, demonstrating a measurable reduction over a 12-month period.
The system must include a fraud detection module that automatically flags at least 90% of known fraudulent pattern types.
The system must be capable of generating reports to audit coverage and treatment distribution across different demographic groups to ensure equity.
System uptime must be 99.9% to ensure continuous access for claims processing and reimbursement.

metadata.raw_input: As a result, health insurance or health purchaser1 information systems are becoming more important as schemes are implemented at national scale. Strong health insurance information systems can ensure timely reimbursements, decrease transaction costs, find system efficiencies, prevent fraud, and ensure equitable coverage and treatment.

title: Health Insurance Data Integration
statement: The system shall be capable of ingesting and integrating health insurance data to complement other existing types of health system data (e.g., clinical, demographic).
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C (Security Rule)
HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E (Privacy Rule)
GDPR - Article 9 (Processing of special categories of personal data)
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide a secure mechanism (e.g., API, SFTP) to import health insurance data from specified sources.
Imported health insurance data must be successfully linked to corresponding patient records within the system with a verifiable accuracy rate of >= 99.5%.
Authorized users can generate reports and perform analytics that combine health insurance data with other health system data.
All access, import, and integration actions involving health insurance data must be logged in an immutable audit trail, compliant with relevant regulations.

metadata.raw_input: Many countries are also finding value in health insurance data to complement other types of health system data.

title: Health Insurance Data Integration
statement: The system shall be capable of integrating and utilizing health insurance data to complement other types of health system data for analysis and reporting.
regulation: HIPAA - Privacy Rule (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E)
HIPAA - Security Rule (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C)
acceptance_criteria: The system provides a mechanism to import or connect to health insurance data sources.
Imported health insurance data can be successfully linked to corresponding patient records within the system.
Authorized users can generate reports that combine health insurance data with other health system data.
All health insurance data is encrypted both in transit and at rest, and all access is logged in an immutable audit trail.

metadata.raw_input: Many countries are also finding value in health insurance data to complement other types of health system data.

title: Purpose and Use of Functional Requirements
statement: Functional requirements are an invaluable tool for policymakers and systems engineering, and technical experts alike.
acceptance_criteria: The project team acknowledges the role of functional requirements as a key tool for development and policy alignment.
Functional requirements are utilized in the system engineering process.

metadata.raw_input: Functional requirements are an invaluable tool for policymakers and systems engineering, and technical experts alike.

title: System Definition of National Priorities
statement: The system shall provide a technical function that allows system experts to gain clarity on national priorities in a format that is directly transferable for software design and implementation.
acceptance_criteria: A system expert can access a dedicated interface presenting the national priorities.
The priorities are displayed in a structured, machine-readable format (e.g., JSON, XML).
The system provides a feature to export the priorities data for use in design and implementation tools.

metadata.raw_input: Technical defines a function of a system experts gain clarity on the national priorities in a format that is transferable to software or its component, where a design and implementation.

title: Cross-Functional Requirement Clarity
statement: All requirements must be documented in a format that is clear and understandable to both business stakeholders (e.g., health insurance experts) and technical implementers (e.g., software engineers), providing a common platform for specification, prioritization, and system design.
acceptance_criteria: A standardized requirements template is created and used for all project requirements.
A formal review process is in place for all requirements, requiring sign-off from at least one technical representative and one business representative.
During sprint planning, developers can articulate the business intent of a requirement, and business stakeholders can confirm the technical scope aligns with their understanding.

metadata.raw_input: These requirements provide a format that is understandable function is described as a to both health insurance experts and software engineers, providing a platform for specification of behavior prioritization, compromise, and system design.

title: Standardized Requirement Specification Format
statement: The system for managing requirements shall provide a specification format that is understandable to both domain experts (e.g., health insurance experts) and technical experts (e.g., software engineers). This format must be transferable to software design and implementation, and serve as a platform for prioritization, compromise, and system design, ensuring clarity on national priorities.
acceptance_criteria: A formal template for requirements is defined and approved by both domain and technical stakeholders.
The requirement format is successfully used to document a sample functional requirement, which is then deemed understandable and actionable by both health insurance experts and software engineers.
The format includes explicit fields for prioritization and traceability to business or regulatory drivers (i.e., 'national priorities').

metadata.raw_input: Technical defines a function of a system experts gain clarity on the national priorities in a format that is transferable to software or its component, where a design and implementation. These requirements provide a format that is understandable function is described as a to both health insurance experts and software engineers, providing a platform for specification of behavior prioritization, compromise, and system design.

title: Configurable Regional/Organizational Requirements
statement: The system must be configurable to accommodate specific compliance, functional, or data handling requirements defined by different countries or organizations.
acceptance_criteria: System administrators must be able to configure rules based on a specific country (e.g., Germany).
System administrators must be able to configure rules based on a specific organization's policy.
The configured rules must be enforced by the system for the specified jurisdiction or organization.
Demonstrate the ability to configure a data retention policy for a specific region.

metadata.raw_input: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs.

title: Common Requirements Baseline
statement: A set of globally defined common requirements shall be established and used as an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.
acceptance_criteria: A documented set of globally defined common requirements exists and is accessible to the development team.
Evidence demonstrates that new projects reference and incorporate applicable common requirements from the defined set.
A process is in place for the periodic review and update of the common requirements set.

metadata.raw_input: The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.

title: Use of Global Requirements Baseline
statement: The development process shall utilize a set of globally defined common requirements as an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources. Country- or organization-specific requirements will be defined and adapted from this common foundation to address unique needs.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence is provided that a recognized set of common/global requirements was used as the initial baseline for project requirements.
A formal review process is documented, showing how the global requirements were evaluated and adapted for specific country or organizational needs.
Traceability is established between the project-specific requirements and the initial global requirements baseline.

metadata.raw_input: A country or organization will define specific requirements for its specific needs. The benefit of a set of globally defined common requirements is to provide an advanced starting point to review best practices and save time and resources in the development process.

title: Standardized Process for Common Requirements
statement: A standardized process must be established and followed for the creation and management of common requirements to ensure consistency, reusability, and clarity, addressing the inherent challenge of defining them effectively.
acceptance_criteria: A documented procedure for creating, reviewing, and managing common requirements exists and is approved.
Evidence demonstrates that the procedure is followed for new projects, including requirement reviews and approvals.
A central repository or tool for managing common requirements is implemented and maintained.

metadata.raw_input: CreAting common requirements While common requirements are a useful building block, creating them can be a challenge.

title: Support for Diverse Health Coverage Schemes
statement: The system must support a variety of country-specific health coverage schemes, accommodating differences in their design, coverage levels, and maturity. This requires a flexible and configurable architecture to function appropriately.
acceptance_criteria: An administrator can configure a new health coverage scheme, defining its specific rules, coverage limits, and reimbursement models.
The system can simultaneously support multiple, distinct health coverage schemes for different regions or populations.
Patient billing and eligibility checks must correctly apply the rules of the relevant, configured health scheme.
The system's configuration for a scheme can be updated without requiring a new software deployment.

metadata.raw_input: Country health coverage schemes range in design, coverage, and maturity—all of which require different types of requirements to function appropriately.

title: Adaptability to Country-Specific Health Schemes
statement: The system must be designed to accommodate and adapt to the diverse designs, coverage levels, and maturity of different country-specific health coverage schemes. This includes supporting varying types of requirements needed for each scheme to function appropriately.
acceptance_criteria: The system can be configured to support at least three distinct country health coverage schemes (e.g., US-based PPO, UK's NHS, German statutory health insurance) without requiring code changes.
Configuration for a new country scheme can be performed by an Admin user through a dedicated interface.
Rules for coverage, billing, and data handling specific to a configured country scheme are correctly applied and can be verified through end-to-end testing scenarios for that country.

metadata.raw_input: CreAting common requirements While common requirements are a useful building block, creating them can be a challenge. Country health coverage schemes range in design, coverage, and maturity—all of which require different types of requirements to function appropriately.

title: CRDM Application Scope
statement: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more.
acceptance_criteria: The system's data model, based on CRDM, is validated to support core use cases for health insurance systems.
The system's data model, based on CRDM, is validated to support core use cases for logistics management information systems.
The system's data model, based on CRDM, is validated to support core use cases for maternal health information systems.

metadata.raw_input: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more.

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.
regulation: ISO - 62366-1 (Application of usability engineering to medical devices)
acceptance_criteria: All user-facing text, including labels, instructions, and error messages, must be reviewed and approved by a panel of representative users (e.g., clinicians, patients) for clarity and avoidance of technical jargon.
Usability testing with target users must demonstrate a task completion success rate of >= 95% for core system functions, with user errors related to language ambiguity being less than 2%.
A formal review of all UI text against a pre-defined glossary of approved, non-technical terms must be completed and passed.

metadata.raw_input: A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.

title: Use of Non-Technical Language
statement: The system must use non-technical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts to ensure effectiveness and ease of use across all interfaces and documentation.
acceptance_criteria: Usability testing with representative users demonstrates a task completion success rate of 95% or higher for key workflows.
A panel of subject matter experts must review and approve all user-facing terminology and labels for clarity and familiarity.
All user-facing text must achieve a Flesch-Kincaid grade level score of 8 or lower.
No technical jargon or system-specific acronyms are present in the user interface without a clear, accessible definition or tooltip.

metadata.raw_input: Since its development, CRDM has been used not only in the health insurance space but also to develop requirements for logistics management information systems, maternal health information systems, and more. A key aspect of the effectiveness of CRDM is the use of nontechnical language that is familiar to users and subject matter experts.

title: Beneficiary Management Capability
statement: The system must provide core beneficiary management capabilities, applicable to all healthcare schemes, regardless of whether a specific scheme requires formal beneficiary enrollment.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C (Security Rule)
HIPAA - 45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E (Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: Given an authorized user, when they access the beneficiary management module, they can create a new beneficiary record.
Given an authorized user, when they search for a beneficiary by a unique identifier (e.g., name, ID), the system returns the correct beneficiary record.
Given an authorized user, when they select a beneficiary record, they can view and update the beneficiary's information.
The system provides a mechanism to manage beneficiaries for schemes that do not have a formal enrollment process.
The system provides a mechanism to manage beneficiaries for schemes that do have a formal enrollment process.

metadata.raw_input: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.

title: Universal Beneficiary Management
statement: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.
regulation: HIPAA - Privacy Rule (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E)
HIPAA - Security Rule (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C)
acceptance_criteria: An authorized user (e.g., Admin) can create, view, update, and deactivate a beneficiary record.
Beneficiary management functions are available and operational for schemes that require formal enrollment.
Beneficiary management functions are available and operational for schemes that do not require formal enrollment.

metadata.raw_input: While some schemes may not require beneficiary enrollment and another may require it, both systems will require some level of beneficiary management.

title: Interoperability via Global Standards
statement: The system shall leverage global standards, such as HL7 FHIR, for data exchange to ensure alignment of business processes and interoperability across disparate digital health systems.
acceptance_criteria: The system's data exchange APIs must be compliant with the specified version of the HL7 FHIR standard.
All data exchange transactions must be successfully validated against a standard FHIR validator tool.
System must demonstrate successful data exchange (e.g., sending a patient summary, receiving lab results) with a third-party test system.
All data exchanged must be encrypted in transit using industry-standard protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2+).
Audit logs are created for all data exchange events, in compliance with HIPAA requirements.

metadata.raw_input: HL7 FHIR HL7 FHIR, and other global standards for data exchange, are helpful frameworks for aligning business processes across digital health systems.

title: Interoperability via Global Standards
statement: The system shall utilize global standards, such as HL7 FHIR, for data exchange to ensure interoperability and alignment of business processes across different digital health systems.
acceptance_criteria: Data exported for key workflows (e.g., patient transfer, lab results reporting) must be in a valid HL7 FHIR format.
The system must successfully consume and correctly process HL7 FHIR-formatted data from a certified external system.
All data exchange transmissions must be encrypted using industry-standard protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2+).
A compliance report must be available demonstrating that all data exchange endpoints adhere to the specified global standards.

metadata.raw_input: HL7 FHIR HL7 FHIR, and other global standards for data exchange, are helpful frameworks for aligning business processes across digital health systems.

title: Business Process Task Set Definition
statement: The system shall support the definition and management of task sets. A task set is defined as a collection of required activities or steps that are carried out as part of a business process.
regulation: FDA 21 CFR Part 820 - Quality System Regulation
acceptance_criteria: An authorized user can create a new task set with a name and description.
The user can add an ordered list of steps or activities to the task set.
The user can save the defined task set to the system.
The user can view and edit an existing task set.
The system prevents the deletion of a task set that is currently associated with an active business process.

metadata.raw_input: • Task set(s): The set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.

title: Task Set Definition
statement: The system shall support the creation and management of Task Sets, which are defined as the set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.
regulation: HIPAA 164.308(a)(1)(ii)(A) - Implementation of policies and procedures
acceptance_criteria: An administrator can define a new Task Set.
A Task Set must contain one or more ordered steps or activities.
The system allows for a Task Set to be associated with a business process.
Users can view the steps of a Task Set relevant to their role and assigned work.

metadata.raw_input: • Task set(s): The set of required activities or steps that are carried out in a business process.

title: Scheme Process Configuration Options
statement: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.
acceptance_criteria: Given an administrator is on the scheme configuration page,
When the administrator views the process options,
Then the system must display a clear, comparative outline of all available processes.
And the administrator must be able to select a process for the scheme.
And the system must allow the administrator to save the selected process configuration.
And upon saving, the system must confirm the update and apply the chosen process to the scheme's workflow.

metadata.raw_input: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.

title: Scheme Process Options Clarity
statement: The system shall outline the differences between available scheme processes, enabling users to understand the breadth of options and choose the processes most relevant to their scheme.
acceptance_criteria: Given an administrator is on the scheme configuration page,
When the administrator views the process selection options,
Then the system must display a clear, comparative summary of each available process.
And the administrator must be able to select and save a process for their scheme.
And the interface for comparing and selecting processes is intuitive and self-explanatory.

metadata.raw_input: By outlining these differences, countries will understand the breadth of options available and choose those processes that are most relevant to their scheme.

title: Business Process Visualization
statement: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.
regulation: FDA - 21 CFR Part 820 - Quality System Regulation
acceptance_criteria: Given a defined business process, the system must render a graphical representation of it.
The graphical representation must visually distinguish and label all actors/roles involved in the process.
The graphical representation must use directional indicators (e.g., arrows) to show the flow of information between actors.
The sequence of tasks or steps in the process must be clearly depicted in the graphical representation.
The user must be able to zoom in/out and pan across the graphical representation for readability.

metadata.raw_input: A graphical representation of a business process helps tell a story of who participates in a process, what types of information are exchanged between the participants, and how the work is accomplished.

title: Beneficiary Insurer Identification Verification
statement: The system must support a process for a beneficiary to present proof of accurate insurer identification, and ensure that the information is validated as required.
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide an interface for an administrative user to input or scan the beneficiary's insurer identification card.
The system must validate the format of the entered insurance information (e.g., member ID, group number).
The system must confirm that the beneficiary's name on the identification matches the name in the patient's record.
The verification process must be logged with the user, date, and time of the action.

metadata.raw_input: Present identification process and/or process will end with beneficiary to ensure it is information as required by the Beneficiary presents proof of accurate insurer identification 5.

title: Beneficiary Insurer Identification Verification
statement: The system must support a process for verifying a beneficiary's identity by requiring them to present proof of accurate insurer identification. The process must ensure the information is validated as required before proceeding.
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide an interface for an authorized user to capture the beneficiary's insurer identification details.
The system must allow the user to confirm that physical or digital proof of identification was presented by the beneficiary.
The system must validate the captured insurer information for accuracy, either through manual confirmation or automated verification.
An audit trail must be created, logging the user, timestamp, and action of the verification.

metadata.raw_input: Present identification process and/or process will end with beneficiary to ensure it is information as required by the Beneficiary presents proof of accurate insurer identification 5.

title: Beneficiary Credential and Plan Qualification Review
statement: The system must allow an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, biometrics) and supporting documents for validity. The Insurer must verify that all required data fields are complete. The system must also provide a mechanism to handle cases where a beneficiary qualifies for multiple benefit plans.
acceptance_criteria: An authorized Insurer user can access the beneficiary's submitted identification information and documents.
The system must display all required fields for beneficiary identification, including name, address, and biometrics.
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to mark the data and documents as 'valid' or 'invalid'.
The system must prevent the enrollment process from proceeding if required fields are incomplete or not validated.
In cases where a beneficiary qualifies for multiple benefit plans, the system must present these plans to the Insurer for selection or further processing.

metadata.raw_input: beneficiary credentials Insurer reviews identification information (i.e., name, address, Insurer reviews the captured In the even that there are several and other appropriate qualifying biometrics…) data to ensure that all of the benefits plans for which the documents for validity appropriate fields are complete beneficiary qualifies, then the 6.

title: Beneficiary Credential and Eligibility Verification
statement: The system must allow an Insurer to review a beneficiary's identification information (e.g., name, address, qualifying biometrics) and supporting documents to verify their validity and ensure all required data fields are complete. The system must also correctly handle cases where a beneficiary qualifies for multiple benefit plans.
acceptance_criteria: An authorized Insurer user can access the beneficiary's submitted identification information and documents.
The system must display all required fields for beneficiary identification, including name, address, and biometrics.
The system must provide a mechanism for the Insurer to mark the data and documents as 'valid' or 'invalid'.
The system must automatically check for and flag incomplete data submissions to the Insurer.
When a beneficiary's data indicates qualification for multiple benefit plans, the system must correctly identify and present all applicable plans to the Insurer.

metadata.raw_input: beneficiary credentials Insurer reviews identification information (i.e., name, address, Insurer reviews the captured In the even that there are several and other appropriate qualifying biometrics…) data to ensure that all of the benefits plans for which the documents for validity appropriate fields are complete beneficiary qualifies, then the 6.

title: Requirement Statement Formatting Standard
statement: All system requirement statements must be written in a clear, unambiguous, and testable format, beginning with the phrase 'The system must...'.
acceptance_criteria: A review of the requirements specification document confirms all requirement statements begin with 'The system must...'.
Requirement documents that do not adhere to this standard are rejected during the formal review process.
All requirements are verifiable and traceable as a result of this standardized format.

metadata.raw_input: statements usually begin with “The system must .

title: Technology-Agnostic Requirement Formulation
statement: All system requirements must be phrased to describe what the system shall accomplish, without making specific references to the underlying technology or implementation details. Requirements should typically begin with 'The system shall...'.
acceptance_criteria: A review of the requirements specification document demonstrates that requirements describe functional outcomes, not implementation methods.
A search of the requirements specification for technology-specific keywords (e.g., 'Oracle', 'React', 'AWS S3', 'REST API') within requirement statements yields no results.
Each functional requirement statement begins with an approved, standardized phrase such as 'The system shall'.

metadata.raw_input: .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.

title: Requirement Statement Formatting Standard
statement: Statements usually begin with “The system must . .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.
acceptance_criteria: All documented system requirements must begin with the phrase 'The system must' or 'The system shall'.

A review of requirement specifications shows that they describe functional or non-functional capabilities without mandating specific implementation technologies (e.g., programming languages, database vendors, or specific hardware).

metadata.raw_input: statements usually begin with “The system must . .”or “The system shall ” and describe what must be accomplished without specific reference to technology.

title: System Process Activity Auditing
statement: The system must automatically record and maintain a secure audit log of all process activities involving access to, creation of, or modification of electronic protected health information (ePHI).
acceptance_criteria: When any actor accesses, creates, or modifies PHI, a corresponding entry is created in the audit log.

Each audit log entry must contain, at a minimum: user identification, date and time of the action, type of action (e.g., view, modify, delete), and the specific data object accessed (e.g., patient ID).
The audit logs must be immutable and protected against unauthorized access, modification, or deletion.
An authorized admin must be able to review and export the audit logs for a specified date range or user.

metadata.raw_input: Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should .

title: Common System Requirement Placeholder
statement: This is a placeholder requirement derived from a document template header: 'Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should ...)'. A specific system behavior needs to be defined here.
acceptance_criteria: 1. The placeholder statement is replaced with a specific, measurable, and testable requirement.
2. The finalized requirement is reviewed and approved by the project stakeholders.
3. The requirement is assigned a definitive priority and severity.

metadata.raw_input: Figure 7 Common system requirements example Requirement Req # Process Activity (the system must or should .

title: Update Global Requirements with Country-Specifics
statement: In turn, country-specific requirements are used to update and expand the global set of requirements.
acceptance_criteria: The system must provide a mechanism to map a new or updated country-specific requirement to the global requirements set.
An authorized user must be able to modify or expand an existing global requirement based on a linked country-specific requirement.
An audit trail must be created that links any changes in the global requirements set to the originating country-specific requirement.

metadata.raw_input: In turn, country-specific requirements are used to update and expand the global set of requirements.

title: Contextual Requirement Analysis
statement: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.
acceptance_criteria: A document is produced that identifies all relevant national policies and scheme designs for the project context.
A set of specific requirements derived from the policy review is created and documented.
The list of derived requirements is approved by the compliance and legal stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.

title: Review of National Policies and Scheme Design
statement: A review of common requirements must be conducted to identify and incorporate all relevant requirements based on the specific context, including national policies and the healthcare scheme's design.
acceptance_criteria: A documented analysis of applicable national policies and scheme design constraints is produced.
A comprehensive list of derived requirements is created and formally approved by the Compliance Officer.
Traceability is established from the identified policies and design constraints to the derived system requirements.

metadata.raw_input: A review of common requirements can help address the question of what requirements are relevant for the context, given national policies and scheme design.

title: Define Functional Scope
statement: The system shall allow an authorized team to define the functional scope of the application.
regulation: GDPR - Article 25 - Data protection by design and by default
acceptance_criteria: Given an authenticated user with 'admin' privileges,
When the user navigates to the system configuration area,
Then they can access an interface to define the application's functional scope.
The user can enable or disable specific features or modules.
Upon saving the configuration, the application's behavior and available functionality must reflect the defined scope for all users.

metadata.raw_input: First, it will allow the team to define what they want to do (i.e., the functional scope).

title: Team Q&A Communication
statement: The system shall provide a secure feature that allows authorized team members to ask essential questions related to patient care and receive answers from other team members.
regulation: HIPAA (Privacy Rule - 45 CFR § 164.502 - Uses and disclosures of protected health information)
acceptance_criteria: An authenticated user with an authorized role (e.g., 'clinician') can access a communication interface.
The user can create and submit a text-based question, optionally linking it to a specific patient record.
The submitted question is visible only to other authorized members of the patient's care team.
All communications (questions and answers) must be logged for audit purposes, capturing the user, timestamp, and patient ID if applicable.
All communication data must be encrypted in transit and at rest.

metadata.raw_input: It will also allow the team to ask essential questions.

title: Functional Scope Definition Capability
statement: The system or process shall provide a mechanism for the development team to define the functional scope of the project. This includes the ability to document features and to ask clarifying questions to stakeholders for requirement validation.
acceptance_criteria: A process or tool exists where the functional scope can be formally documented.
The documented scope is version-controlled and accessible to all designated team members.
A mechanism exists to ask questions related to the scope, and for those questions and their answers to be logged and tracked.

metadata.raw_input: First, it will allow the team to define what they want to do (i.e., the functional scope). It will also allow the team to ask essential questions.

title: Country-Specific Regulatory Analysis
statement: The system must be analyzed to identify and document all relevant national and scheme-specific rules and regulations for the target country of deployment to ensure full compliance.
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive list of all applicable national and scheme-specific rules for the target country is documented.
A compliance matrix is created, mapping each identified rule to system features, policies, or controls.
A gap analysis report is produced, detailing any areas where the system does not meet the required regulations and outlining a remediation plan.

metadata.raw_input: For example: • What are the requirements that will be relevant for our country context given our national and scheme rules?

title: Provider and Payer Side Requirements Definition
statement: The system development process must include the definition, documentation, and approval of all functional, non-functional, and compliance requirements for both provider-facing and payer-facing features and workflows.
acceptance_criteria: A finalized and approved Provider Requirements Document (PRD) is produced.
A finalized and approved Payer Requirements Document (PRD) is produced.
Both documents explicitly address relevant regulatory controls (e.g., HIPAA Security and Privacy Rules).
Requirements are traceable to business objectives and stakeholder needs.

metadata.raw_input: • What requirements must be developed on the provider and payer sides?

title: Country-Specific Regulatory and Role-Based Requirement Analysis
statement: An analysis must be conducted to identify and document all healthcare requirements relevant to the specific country context, including national laws and local scheme rules. This analysis must also define and differentiate the specific requirements that need to be developed for both provider and payer systems/roles.
acceptance_criteria: A comprehensive document is created that lists all identified national and scheme-specific rules applicable to the project.
A distinct set of functional and non-functional requirements for the provider side is documented and approved.
A distinct set of functional and non-functional requirements for the payer side is documented and approved.
The analysis and resulting requirements are formally reviewed and signed off by the legal and compliance teams.

metadata.raw_input: For example: • What are the requirements that will be relevant for our country context given our national and scheme rules? • What requirements must be developed on the provider and payer sides?

title: Hospital Information System (HIS) Integration
statement: The solution must be capable of integrating with existing hospital information systems (HIS) to facilitate seamless data exchange. If direct integration is not supported, a dedicated interface must be designed and built.
acceptance_criteria: The solution can successfully establish a connection with a target HIS using standard interoperability protocols (e.g., HL7, FHIR).
Patient data can be successfully queried and retrieved from the HIS and displayed accurately within the solution.
Data created or modified in the solution can be successfully transmitted back to the HIS, if applicable.
All data transmitted between the solution and the HIS must be encrypted in transit.
The integration must include robust error handling for connection failures and data synchronization issues to prevent data loss or corruption.

metadata.raw_input: • Will the solution integrate with existing hospital information systems, or will it need to have interface design built into it?

title: Requirement Prioritization
statement: A mechanism must be established to classify requirements as either essential (must-have) or non-essential (nice-to-have) to guide development, validation, and release planning.
acceptance_criteria: A field or tag is available for each requirement to mark its essentiality (e.g., 'Essential', 'Nice-to-have').
The project's requirements documentation or backlog can be filtered and sorted based on this classification.
The criteria for what constitutes an 'Essential' requirement are clearly defined and documented, referencing factors like patient safety, regulatory compliance, and core clinical workflow.

metadata.raw_input: • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: Integration with Hospital Information Systems (HIS)
statement: The solution must be capable of integrating with existing hospital information systems (e.g., EHR, LIS, RIS). The requirement analysis must determine if standard interfaces (e.g., HL7, FHIR) can be used or if custom interface design is required. The priority of specific integrations (essential vs. nice-to-have) must be defined.
acceptance_criteria: The system can establish a secure, bi-directional connection with a specified target HIS (e.g., an EHR via a FHIR API).
The system can successfully query and retrieve patient data from the connected HIS in real-time.
The system can successfully write or update patient data in the connected HIS without data corruption.
All data transmitted between the solution and the HIS is encrypted in transit using TLS 1.2 or higher.
The integration includes robust error handling for connection failures, data mismatches, and timeouts, with events logged for administrative review.

metadata.raw_input: • Will the solution integrate with existing hospital information systems, or will it need to have interface design built into it? • Are there any requirements that are essential to address while others would be nice to have but not essential?

title: Solution Evaluation and Selection
statement: The system shall provide a mechanism for managers to evaluate multiple solution alternatives and select the system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.
acceptance_criteria: A user with an 'Admin' or 'Manager' role can access a 'Solution Evaluation' module.
The system allows the user to input and manage multiple solution alternatives for comparison.
The user can define, customize, and weight evaluation criteria (e.g., cost, feature set, compliance, usability).
The system must generate a comparative view (e.g., a scorecard or side-by-side table) of the alternatives against the defined criteria.
The user can select a preferred solution and generate a summary report of the evaluation.

metadata.raw_input: EvAluAte solutions Sometimes managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.

title: Evaluate Solution Alternatives
statement: Managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.
regulation: HIPAA - Security Rule - 45 CFR § 164.308(a)(1)(ii)(A) Risk Analysis
GDPR - Article 25: Data protection by design and by default
acceptance_criteria: A documented process for evaluating and selecting systems is established and followed.
A comparison matrix is used to evaluate solution alternatives against predefined organizational, technical, and compliance requirements.
The final selection is justified and documented, demonstrating how the chosen system best meets the organization's needs.
Due diligence on vendor compliance and security posture is performed and documented.

metadata.raw_input: EvAluAte solutions Sometimes managers will be in a position where they have multiple solution alternatives and need to choose a system that best matches the complex and diverse organizational needs.

title: Software Evaluation Trade-offs
statement: The evaluation and selection process must acknowledge that different software packages will exhibit varying levels of strength across the full set of requirements. A weighted scoring mechanism must be used to objectively assess and compare solutions based on the defined priority of each requirement.
acceptance_criteria: A documented evaluation plan is established, which includes a weighted scoring model for requirements.
The final software selection report explicitly shows the application of the weighted scoring model to compare candidate solutions.
The weighting in the scoring model is directly informed by the priority assigned to each requirement.

metadata.raw_input: Not every software package will be equally strong across all requirements.

title: Software Evaluation Trade-offs
statement: Acknowledge that different software solutions will exhibit varying levels of strength and compliance across the full spectrum of requirements. A risk-based approach and a weighted scoring matrix must be used during software selection and procurement to evaluate these trade-offs.
regulation: GDPR - Art. 25 Data protection by design and by default
acceptance_criteria: A documented software evaluation process exists that includes a weighted scoring mechanism.
For any software procurement, a completed evaluation matrix is produced, showing the comparison of potential solutions against key requirements.
The final selection decision is documented, including a justification for any accepted trade-offs and associated risk mitigation plans.

metadata.raw_input: Not every software package will be equally strong across all requirements.

title: Requirements-Driven Development
statement: Software developers must be able to define and implement the functionality of the software using the detailed and approved business development processes and requirements documentation.
acceptance_criteria: All software features developed must be traceable to a corresponding documented business requirement.
Evidence of developers referencing the business process and requirements documents is present in task tracking systems or code commit messages.
A formal design and development plan, as required by quality system regulations, is established and followed.

metadata.raw_input: Guide softwAre Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business develoPment processes and requirements.

title: Implementation Flexibility
statement: Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.
acceptance_criteria: Requirements are verified to specify intended use, inputs, and outputs without dictating specific implementation details.
Design reviews demonstrate that the chosen technical solution effectively meets the objectives of the requirement.
Validation testing confirms that the final output and outcome match the requirement's goals, irrespective of the implementation method.

metadata.raw_input: Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.

title: Functional Definition from Business Requirements
statement: Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business development processes and requirements. Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.
acceptance_criteria: The software development lifecycle (SDLC) process documentation must show how business requirements are translated into software design inputs.
Design outputs (e.g., code, architecture) must be traceable back to the originating business requirements.

Verification and validation test cases must confirm that the final software's inputs, outputs, and outcomes meet the objectives defined in the business requirements, regardless of the specific implementation method used.

metadata.raw_input: Guide softwAre Software developers are able to define the functionality of a software using the detailed business develoPment processes and requirements. Because requirements do not specifically address how a process should be carried out, software developers are able to apply different software solutions to ensure the inputs, outputs, and outcomes match the intended objectives and goals.

title: Common Requirements Baseline for Customization
statement: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.
acceptance_criteria: A version-controlled common requirements document (CRD) is established and maintained as the baseline for software design.
The software architecture documentation explicitly demonstrates how the design supports customization for different regions or systems.
A defined process exists for proposing, approving, and implementing country-specific or system-specific requirements that deviate from or extend the CRD.

metadata.raw_input: While software may have to be further customized to meet the specific needs of a country or system, a common requirements document provides a starting point for software design and can help software developers create a product that fulfills needs across scheme designs and structures.

title: CRDM Process for Requirement and Process Documentation
statement: The CRDM (Collaborative Requirements Development Methodology) process shall be used to systematically identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and document all project-specific business processes and their related requirements.
acceptance_criteria: All project requirements must be documented in a standardized format traceable to CRDM process outputs (e.g., workshop minutes, decision logs).
Evidence must be provided that relevant stakeholders (actors) participated in the identification, discussion, and agreement stages of the CRDM process.
A formal sign-off record must exist for all documented business processes and requirements.
The project's Quality Plan must reference the use of the CRDM process for requirements engineering.

metadata.raw_input: Use DescriPtion Use the CRDM Process to CRDM is a generic process and can be used to identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and develoP Project-sPecific document any business process and its related requirements systematically.

title: Local Requirement Analysis and Consensus
statement: An analysis and consensus-building exercise must be conducted at the country or project level to validate and adapt generic requirements, even when pre-mapped generic processes and requirements are available in a master document.
acceptance_criteria: Evidence of a review and consensus-building meeting (e.g., meeting minutes) is available for each country or project implementation.
A document is produced detailing the localized analysis, including any adaptations or justifications for using the generic requirements as-is.
Sign-off on the localized requirements is obtained from relevant country or project-level stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: Some key processes requirements and requirements were already mapped in this document in a way that should be as generic as possible; but even then, value may be found in the analysis and consensus-building aspect of the exercise itself at a country or project level.

title: Use of CRDM Process for Requirement Definition
statement: The CRDM (Consensus-based Requirements Definition Methodology) process must be used to systematically identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and document all business processes and their related project-specific requirements. This process shall be applied at the country and/or project level to facilitate analysis and consensus-building.
acceptance_criteria: A formal CRDM process is documented and available.
Project plans include scheduled CRDM activities for requirement gathering and consensus-building.
Outputs from the CRDM process (e.g., meeting minutes, signed-off requirement specifications) are produced and stored for each project.
There is auditable evidence of stakeholder agreement on the requirements documented via the CRDM process.

metadata.raw_input: Use DescriPtion Use the CRDM Process to CRDM is a generic process and can be used to identify, discuss, reach agreement on, and develoP Project-sPecific document any business process and its related requirements systematically. Some key processes requirements and requirements were already mapped in this document in a way that should be as generic as possible; but even then, value may be found in the analysis and consensus-building aspect of the exercise itself at a country or project level.

title: Cross-Check Materials and Requirements
statement: Materials can be cross-checked against requirements to ensure they align with one another and that all processes are covered by both.
acceptance_criteria: A traceability matrix exists that maps requirements to design documents, test cases, and other materials.
A documented review process is in place for cross-checking materials against requirements.
Evidence of completed reviews (e.g., sign-offs, review reports) is available for audit.
All defined processes are demonstrably covered by both requirements and corresponding materials.

metadata.raw_input: Materials can be cross-checked against requirements to ensure they align with one another and that all processes are covered by both.

title: Improve Data Quality
statement: The system must implement mechanisms to improve and maintain a high level of data quality, addressing common issues such as inaccuracies, incompleteness, and inconsistencies in patient and clinical data.
regulation: HIPAA - Security Rule - 45 CFR § 164.308(a)(1)(ii)(B) - Integrity Controls
acceptance_criteria: Data entry fields for critical data (e.g., date of birth, medication dosage) must have built-in validation rules to prevent common errors.
The system must provide a feature to identify and flag potential duplicate patient records for administrative review and merging.
An audit trail must be automatically generated for any modification to PHI, capturing the user, timestamp, and the change made.
The system must provide a dashboard for administrators to view data quality metrics, such as percentage of incomplete records or data entry error rates.

metadata.raw_input: ImProve dAtA quAlity Issues with data quality are common.

title: Data Flow and Lifecycle Analysis
statement: A comprehensive analysis of business processes must be conducted and documented to determine all points where data enters the system (both directly collected and from integrated systems), all methods by which data are processed and analyzed, and all mechanisms by which data are shared with internal users and external systems.
regulation: HIPAA Security Rule - 45 CFR § 164.308(a)(1)(ii)(A) Risk Analysis
HIPAA Privacy Rule - 45 CFR § 164.502 Uses and disclosures of protected health information
GDPR - Article 30, Records of processing activities
acceptance_criteria: A complete data flow diagram (DFD) exists, mapping all data ingress, processing, storage, and egress points.
Documentation is available that identifies every system component, user role, and external entity that interacts with the data.
The analysis report details the types of data (e.g., PHI, PII) involved in each step of the data flow.
The data flow analysis and associated documentation have been reviewed and approved by the designated Security and Compliance Officers.

metadata.raw_input: An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.

title: Data Quality and Integrity Analysis
statement: The system must support the analysis of business processes to ensure data quality throughout its lifecycle. This includes identifying data entry points (direct collection and system-to-system), and tracking how data is processed, analyzed, and shared with users and other systems to mitigate data quality issues.
regulation: FDA - 21 CFR Part 11 - Electronic Records; Electronic Signatures
acceptance_criteria: A data lineage capability must exist to trace data from its source to its points of use and sharing.
The system must be able to generate reports on data validation success and failure rates at all data entry points.
An audit trail must be available to track all processing and transformation steps applied to data.
System documentation must map data flows for all key business processes, including ingestion, processing, and sharing.

metadata.raw_input: ImProve dAtA quAlity Issues with data quality are common. An analysis of business processes can help determine where data are entering the system (either directly collected or coming from another system), how data are processed and analyzed, and how data are shared with users and other systems.

title: Stakeholder Data Access for Business Process Management
statement: The system shall provide authorized stakeholders with the necessary reporting and data analysis tools to effectively identify, monitor, and resolve issues within specific business processes by providing access to relevant data.
regulation: HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart C - Security Rule)
HIPAA (45 CFR Part 164, Subpart E - Privacy Rule)
acceptance_criteria: Given an authorized stakeholder (e.g., Business Analyst), when they navigate to the reporting module, they can select a specific business process (e.g., Patient Intake).
The system must display a dashboard with relevant KPIs and metrics for the selected business process.
The user must be able to filter the data by date range and other relevant parameters (e.g., location, department) to investigate specific issues.
The system must provide a feature to export the filtered data or report in a standard format (e.g., CSV, PDF).
All access to data containing PHI for reporting purposes must be recorded in the system's audit log, detailing the user, timestamp, and data accessed.

metadata.raw_input: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.

title: Stakeholder Data Access for Business Processes
statement: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.
regulation: HIPAA - 45 CFR 164.502 (Uses and disclosures of protected health information)
acceptance_criteria: Given a user with a 'Business Analyst' role, when they access the reporting module, they can generate reports tailored to specific business processes (e.g., patient intake, claims submission).
The generated reports must contain the necessary data fields to allow for the identification and analysis of process-specific issues.
Users must be able to filter and query data within the reports to investigate specific cases or trends.
All access to data through this functionality must be logged in an immutable audit trail, accessible by an 'Administrator' or 'Compliance Officer'.

metadata.raw_input: Stakeholders are better able to address these specific issues and address data needs of each business process.

title: Resource Usability and Maintainability
statement: The resource should be sustainably maintained, and all documentation/resources must be easily usable (e.g., downloadable, referenceable, and adaptable).
acceptance_criteria: All user documentation and resources are available in a common, downloadable format (e.g., PDF).
Documentation sections must be individually referenceable via unique URLs or anchors.
Where applicable, resources are provided in an adaptable format (e.g., templates in DOCX) to allow for local customization.
A version history for all documentation is maintained and accessible.
The process for updating and maintaining documentation is defined and auditable.

metadata.raw_input: The resource should be sustainably maintained, and all documentation/resources must be easily usable (e.g., downloadable, referenceable, and adaptable).

title: Scalable System for National Health Insurance
statement: The information system must be effective and scalable to support the expansion of access to health services through national health insurance schemes.
acceptance_criteria: The system must support a load of 1 million concurrent users with an average API response time of less than 500ms.
The system must demonstrate the capacity to process 10 million insurance claims per 24-hour period.
The system architecture must support horizontal scaling to accommodate a 10x growth in user base over 5 years without major re-architecture.
System uptime must be maintained at 99.95% or higher under peak load conditions.

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems.

title: Feasibility of Common Functional Requirements for National Health Insurance Systems
statement: An analysis must be conducted to determine the feasibility and definition of a set of common functional requirements for national health insurance systems, addressing the historical challenge of limited system reuse from country to country.
acceptance_criteria: A feasibility study report is produced that analyzes the functional requirements of at least three different national health insurance systems.
The report identifies a core set of common functional requirements that are viable for a reusable system.
The report documents reasons for historical lack of reuse and proposes mitigation strategies.
The defined set of common requirements is reviewed and approved by key project stakeholders.

metadata.raw_input: At the outset, experts questioned if common functional requirements were possible since to date there has been little reuse of national health insurance systems from country to country.

title: Common Functional Requirements for National Health Insurance Systems
statement: The national health insurance information system must be built upon a set of common, reusable functional requirements to ensure it is effective and scalable, facilitating the expansion of health services to citizens globally. The design should address the historical challenge of limited reuse of such systems from country to country.
acceptance_criteria: A core set of common functional requirements is defined, documented, and approved.
The system architecture supports modularity and reuse of functional components across different regions or deployments.
Performance and load testing validates the system's ability to scale to a national level, meeting defined transaction and user volume targets.
A successful pilot deployment validates the effectiveness and reusability of the core functional components.

metadata.raw_input: Conclusion Globally, countries are expanding access to health services to more of their citizens through the development of national health insurance schemes; the success of these efforts is highly dependent upon effective and scalable information systems. At the outset, experts questioned if common functional requirements were possible since to date there has been little reuse of national health insurance systems from country to country.

title: Shared Functional Requirements Across Geographies
statement: The system shall support a common set of functional requirements that are shared across different countries, as identified through the application of the Clinical Research Data Model (CRDM).
acceptance_criteria: A document defining the common functional requirements derived from the CRDM for all targeted countries is approved.
System design documents demonstrate how these common functional requirements are implemented in a harmonized way.
Test cases exist and pass, verifying the core functionality works as expected in simulated environments for at least two different countries.

metadata.raw_input: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.

title: Cross-Country Functional Requirement Harmonization
statement: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.
acceptance_criteria: A core set of functional requirements is identified and documented as common across all targeted countries.
The system architecture must be designed to support a common codebase for the identified shared functional requirements.
Country-specific variations are managed through configuration or localization settings, not through separate application builds.
Validation demonstrates that a core function (e.g., patient registration) works consistently across configurations for at least two different countries.

metadata.raw_input: Through the application of the CRDM, it is clear that countries do share many of the same functional requirements.
